HEADLINE: How Essential Is Indian Point?

BYLINE: MATTHEW L. WALD


HIGHLIGHT: Not very, proponents of a shutdown of the nuclear plant insist; but that all depends on how heavy the demand for electricity in the New York metropolitan area turns out to be in coming years. 

 BODY:
 As I reported in Tuesday's paper, opponents of the Indian Point nuclear power plant assert that its two reactors can be retired in the next few years because alternatives exist that pose less risk and would not cost substantially more. New York City's position, however, is that retiring the reactors would raise prices sharply and reduce reliability. 
So, what would those alternatives be? New York's electricity infrastructure resembles its highway system, prone to saturation. Once in a while, though, new transmission capacity does gets added. 
 This month, in a little-noticed development, the Bayonne Energy Center finished a 6.75-mile cable that runs from Bayonne, N.J., under the Kill Van Kull, through Upper New York Bay to Gowanus Bay and then to Con Edison's Gowanus substation. The company plans to build a 512-megawatt gas-fired power station on the New Jersey side.
 In May, work began on a 660-megawatt cable that would run eight miles from Ridgefield, N.J., to Pier 92 in Manhattan, and then to Con Edison's 49th Street substation. Six miles of it will be underwater. 
 Opponents are also counting on projects like the Champlain-Hudson Express, a 1,000-megawatt submarine line that would connect Hydro Quebec with New York City. The two Indian Point reactors produce a bit over 2,000 megawatts.

Opponents of Indian Point commissioned a study from the research and consulting firm Synapse Energy Economics. Synapse acknowledged that the effect of closing Indian Point was hard to predict because it depends partly on the overall level of electricity demand in the New York City area. 
Synapse said that part of the portfolio of alternatives should be a high level of improvement in energy efficiency, effectively cutting demand by 1.5 percent from what it would be otherwise. 
Under Gov. Eliot Spitzer, New York State committed itself to reducing its energy use to 15 percent below "business as usual" by 2015. At the Natural Resources Defense Council, one of the groups that sponsored the Synapse study, Ashok Gupta, an energy expert, acknowledged that the state is "not on target" to meet the Spitzer goal, let alone a tougher one. But he pointed out that some smaller states like Vermont had achieved such reductions. 
The feasibility study is part of a broader effort by Mr. Gupta's group and Riverkeeper, the study's other sponsor, to position themselves for license renewal hearings on Indian Point that are expected to start in the spring. At the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, Scott Burnell, a spokesman, said, "I can't remember any license renewal proceeding that has been this involved." 
The runners-up in terms of controversy are probably Oyster Creek in New Jersey, which eventually won a 20-year extension but whose owners promised to shut it in 2020 in a deal with state environmental regulators, and Pilgrim in Plymouth, Mass., a renewal process that is still under way. 
So far the commission has not turned down any , although it has instructed some applicants to do more work.

HEADLINE: Spin Recycle: What the Post-Debate Debate Might Be

BYLINE: MICHAEL D. SHEAR


HIGHLIGHT: A post-debate process that once was an organic effort, the "spin room" is now an expected and well-orchestrated part of a debate. After seeing the previous action, it is not hard to guess what will be said if patterns hold. 

 BODY:
If a presidential campaign is a test of a candidate's ability to govern, the moments immediately after a presidential debate measure a campaign's ability to twist, manipulate, cajole and spin members of the press.
In a few hours, tonight's debate will be over and reporters will flock to a nearby room where campaign surrogates -- and sometimes the candidate himself -- will explain away gaffes and strategically emphasize the good moments.
A post-debate process that was once an organic effort by those closest to the candidates, the "spin room" is now an expected and well-orchestrated part of the debate. Preprinted signs on long sticks declare "Romney" or "Bachmann" or "Perry" so that reporters at the debate venue can find their way.
In most cases, those doing the spin are professionals: the strategists, pollsters and "senior advisers." Often, the campaigns will bring in the big guns -- former politicians, current lawmakers, ex-governors and the occasional business executive who can vouch for how well their candidate did.
And then there are candidates like Rick Santorum, whose shoestring campaign doesn't go for all those fancy trappings. Standing under the "Santorum" sign after a debate is none other than Mr. Santorum.
So what will these spinners say after tonight's debate in Las Vegas? Having seen them in action at several of the previous seven debates, it's not hard to guess what they will say if past patterns hold up. So let's try: 
MITT ROMNEY: The spinners for the former Massachusetts governor will say he stuck to his theme of being the right "turnaround" guy to fix the ailing economy. He was "authentic," they will insist, despite efforts by his rivals to remind voters of his changed positions on abortion.
And that health care thing? Not a big deal, they will say. He dealt with it months ago, and besides, he wants to rip President Obama's health care law out by the roots. What about his Mormon faith? A big shrug from the spinners and a look of stern disappointment, as if to say: "Really? You're going there?"
RICK PERRY: There's no question, the Perry spinners will say, that our candidate is not a great debater. But really, Americans want a leader, not a debater in chief. He was better, they will say, on the economy and Texas's record of job growth under his tenure as governor. (Did you know he created one million jobs? they will ask.)
Sure, Mr. Perry stumbled with his answers a few times, they will concede. But he was more alert and focused. And the exchange with Mr. Romney about health care? That was pure gold for Mr. Perry, they will insist. Immigration? Look, Mr. Perry is never going to apologize for caring about children, they will say.
HERMAN CAIN: If the past is any guide, Mr. Cain might be his own spinner. And this will be an important night for him. His 9-9-9 plan was well received, he will say. Can it pass? Of course it can, he will say, if the people want it to. And they will!
Now on that pesky issue of the electrified fence on the border? Yes, it was a joke. But the issue of border security will be no joke under a Cain administration, he will say. And no, he will say (though he will be tempted) I won't sing for you.
MICHELE BACHMANN: The spinners for Mrs. Bachmann are used to this by now. Their candidate did fine, they will say. She spoke out when she could, was forceful and knowledgeable. She's a former tax lawyer, you know. And did you see how she landed those criticisms of Mr. Perry, Mr. Romney and Mr. Cain?
The key message for Mrs. Bachmann's presidential campaign, they will say, is this: Don't settle! If voters agree, they will pick her. If they don't, the spinners will insist, they may very well pick Mr. Romney, Mr. Perry or someone else with a lesser record on issues that people care about. And if Mr. Romney would pull "Obamacare" out by the roots, Mrs. Bachmann will drive a stake through its heart.
RON PAUL: If there are spinners at all, they will say this: It's all about liberty. Mr. Paul's plan -- released just this week -- calls for a $1 trillion cut in Year 1 of a Paul administration and a balanced budget by Year 3.
Can that pass? Of course, they will say. The people don't want big government, so getting rid of half a dozen federal agencies will inspire them. Remember: liberty.
NEWT GINGRICH: Mr. Gingrich sometimes saunters into the spin room himself. If not, his supporters will be there to insist that the news media are trying to keep Republicans at each other's throats. Mr. Gingrich was the one person defending the party's need to come together.
And he's the one with the big ideas, they will say. On immigration, the courts, housing and a variety of other more obscure areas of federal policy, Mr. Gingrich was the most loquacious, they will note.
RICK SANTORUM: Mr. Santorum, a former senator, will almost certainly be his own spinner, reminding the reporters gathered around him about his ability to win tough elections in a Democratic state, Pennsylvania. (You know, I beat one of James Carville's candidates, he will proudly say.)
Mr. Santorum will also echo Mrs. Bachmann. The debate proved that voters don't have to settle, he will say. They have in front of them a conservative candidate who is right on abortion, gun rights, taxes and spending (me). Oh, and I won in Pennsylvania.

HEADLINE: As Economy Goes, So Go Takeovers, Even as Bargains Abound

BYLINE: STEVEN M. DAVIDOFF


HIGHLIGHT: Market influences should be putting wind in deal makers' sails, but the Deal Professor says the overall trend is that of M.&#038;A. rushing toward a cliff. 

 BODY:
The merger market is like a pack of lemmings. If the economy is good , the takeover market will follow, but when times are bad, the market stalls.
For the moment, there are still mega-deals, like Kinder Morgan's $21.1 billion acquisition of the El Paso Corporation, and takeover activity is up. The volume of global mergers and acquisitions was up 22 percent, to $2.748 trillion, for the last 12 months ending in August from the period a year ago, according to Thomson Reuters. The increase in deal volume was driven in part by a threefold increase in hostile offers and strong company balance sheets.
Yet many major economies in the world are growing sluggishly, if at all. The negative economic outlook is likely to counteract some otherwise strong drivers for deal-making.
The International Monetary Fund estimates growth for advanced economies at just 1.6 percent this year and only 1.9 percent in 2012, compared with a historical average of about 3 percent. In the United States, unemployment remains stubbornly high, and 2011 G.D.P. growth was recently estimated by a National Association for Business Economics poll of economists to be about 1.57 percent.
The European sovereign debt crisis has worsened the economic growth problem. And the uncertainty over how far the crisis will spread in Europe is bound to drive down takeover volume.
Then there is the stock market. In a presentation last week at the Penn State M&A Institute, Jane Wheeler, a senior managing director at Evercore Partners, noted that since 1985, takeover volume had grown in only two years when the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index had declined.
So we have the lemmings problem again. Takeover volume follows the stock market, and the market is down. Its recovery is fragile given the negative trends.
Also weighing on the merger market are signs that the Obama administration is stepping up antitrust enforcement. Last year, the federal government made a second request for information, an indication of an in-depth investigation of a transaction, in 4.1 percent of deals, compared with 2.5 percent in the last year of the Bush administration, according to a joint report submitted to Congress by the Federal Trade Commission and Department of Justice.
Mergers are also being challenged more often, and antitrust enforcement appears to be becoming even more aggressive in recent months. Although Continental and United Airlines cleared antitrust review by the Obama administration in August 2010, the federal government is suing to stop AT&T's acquisition of T-Mobile USA after effectively blocking Nasdaq's bid to acquire NYSE Euronext and Avis's effort to acquire Dollar Thrifty.
All this spells a decline in takeover volume. Deal makers do not want to take undue risks, and fear of uncertainty and a downturn is real even beyond the heightened regulatory scrutiny.
Yet there remain some forces that should be putting wind in deal makers' sails.
The takeover market's pattern of following equity prices is counterintuitive. When stocks are down, valuations are low and takeovers should make the most sense from a value perspective. Right now, price-earnings multiples are about 15 times earnings, compared, according to Standard & Poor's, with a historical average approaching 20 times earnings. One would think companies would be rushing to scoop up low-priced assets.
This is particularly true since credit is easy, at least for some. The high-yield market is choppy at best, but good companies can borrow at incredibly low rates for long periods. The Norfolk Southern Corporation, for example, priced a $400 million 100-year bond with a yield of 6 percent.
Even beyond credit there is cash, and companies have plenty of it. Standard & Poor's estimates that American companies have more than $2 trillion of cash on their balance sheets. Although much of it is held abroad as companies wait for the federal government to lower the dividend tax on the repatriation of cash, certainly hundreds of millions of dollars can be spent domestically.
Private equity firms are also sitting on big cash hoards. Globally, private equity still has almost $1 trillion in dry powder, according to a study by Bain. Leveraged buyouts currently average a mix of about 40 percent equity and 60 percent debt. Private equity therefore has enough firepower for more than $2 trillion in buyouts.
So where are they? The industry remains notably hesitant to make deals. Only 6.5 percent of global M.& A. transactions through the first nine months of 2011 were private equity acquisitions, according to Dealogic.
While it is hard to know what in particular is holding private equity back, they too are most likely following the economic cycle, afraid to invest in a volatile, potentially down market.
Must-do deals will still happen, like the El Paso acquisition, which Kinder Morgan's chairman and chief executive, Richard D. Kinder, called a "once-in-a-lifetime transaction."
Yet the overall trend is that of M.&A. rushing toward a cliff. Companies that might have pulled the trigger on an acquisition will instead spend their cash on dividends and stock buybacks.
Sure, some brave companies will take a plunge and try to acquire at a lower value. And the slowdown in initial public offerings may also spur takeover activity.
These are likely to be small blips. For the next few months, investment bankers are going to have a hard year as they try to point to the positive factors in the market to sell deals. But they are going to be running against those lemmings.

HEADLINE: The Early Word: Rolling

BYLINE: ASHLEY SOUTHALL


HIGHLIGHT: The latest political news from today's Times and around the Web, plus a look at what's happening in Washington. 

 BODY:
In Today's Times:

        
The wheels on President Obama's armored bus are rolling 'round and 'round through North Carolina and Virginia as the president promotes piecemeal passage of the components of his jobs bill and tries to regain the support that helped him capture both of those swing states in 2008, Mark Landler writes.

        
The Obama administration decided earlier this year against waging cyberwarfare in Libya aimed at Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's government amid doubts about setting a precedent for Russia and China, the president's authority to launch an attack, and the military's preparedness to execute it, Eric Schmitt and Thom Shanker report.

        
Representative Joe Walsh of Illinois was swept into office last year as Republicans rode a wave of Tea Party support to win his seat, but his financial problems may pose a threat to his re-election effortsas he faces the likelihood of running against another Republican freshman in a primary race for his redrawn Congressional district, Jennifer Steinhauer and Steven Yaccino write.

        
Despite his strong and steady performance on the campaign trail, former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts still faces formidable challenges to becoming the Republican Party's presidential nominee, with the primary season two months away and a new CNN poll showing two-thirds of G.O.P. voters undecided about who should run against Mr. Obama, Jeff Zeleny and Ashley Parker write. Mr. Romney will debate six of his rivals Tuesday night in Nevada.

        
As her presidential campaign loses its luster, Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota has reverted to a basic strategy of meeting face to face with voters in the hope that they will give her a second look, Trip Gabriel writes.

        
Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is facing questions about whether his presidential campaign underreported the value of his use of a private jet that, had it been rented from a private charter company, would have cost triple the $21,000 reported on financial disclosures, Richard A. Oppel, Jr. and Jim Rutenberg report.

        
A deficit-reduction panel linked to the Tea Party plans to release a survey Tuesday showing broad support for repealing the 2008 health care overhaul law and eliminating some entire federal departments for an estimated $6 trillion in savings, Kate Zernike reports.

        
Adam Liptak writes that the Supreme Court will consider whether lying about military awards is protected speech under the First Amendment, and, separately, observes Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr.'s struggle to balance the law with what's fair.

        
The huge black holein front of the White House, a steady stream of workers, and the silence surrounding the project have ignited much speculation about what's going on down there, Will Storey writes.
Around the Web:

        
While almost two-thirds of voters are hoping Mr. Obama's policies will work, roughly as many believe they will fail, according to a CNN poll released on Monday. The poll also put Mr. Romney in a tie with Herman Cain ahead of Tuesday's debate.
Happening in Washington:

        
At 8:30 a.m., The Labor Department releases its producer price index for September.

        
In the Senate, the Labor Committee explores options for older Americans in the economic recovery, the Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee examines post-Sept. 11 safeguards against biological threats, and Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner appears before the Small Business Committee for a discussion on federal aid to small businesses. All three hearings begin at 10 a.m.

        
Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. makes two stops in Pennsylvania today to highlight provisions in Mr. Obama's jobs bill designed to support education and public safety. His first stop is at 10:45 a.m. in York and the second is at 3 p.m. in Philadelphia.

        
At noon, Vicente Fox, the former Mexican president, discusses legalizing drugs as a way of dealing with drug abuse in an appearance at the Cato Institute.

LENGTH: 1037 words

HEADLINE: Virginia Reveals Challenges Ahead for Obama

BYLINE: MICHAEL D. SHEAR


HIGHLIGHT: President Obama arrives in Virginia today, at a time when some Democratic candidates there are running away from him. 

 BODY:
President Obama arrives in Virginia on his bus tour today, just as some Democratic candidates for the state legislature are running away from him.
Ward Armstrong, the top Democrat in the House of Delegates, is one of several incumbents up for re-election in the state's off-year elections three weeks from now. And he's one of several who have been tied to Mr. Obama by Republican rivals.
"Now Charles Poindexter is comparing me to Barack Obama," Mr. Armstrong says in a television ad this month. "That's a stretch, Charles. I'm pro-life, pro-gun and I always put Virginia first. That's why I opposed the cap-and-trade bill."
The ad - and others like it in the state - underscores the challenge for Mr. Obama, who narrowly won the state in 2008 as part of a successful effort to campaign in places normally considered hostile to Democratic presidential candidates.
To win re-election next year, Mr. Obama's team is eager to keep Virginia and its 13 electoral votes in their column. But with polls showing Mr. Obama's approval ratings slipping here, Republicans, including Virginia's governor, say a repeat of his 2008 victory is increasingly unlikely.
"I don't see the magic reoccurring," Gov. Bob McDonnell said in an interview Monday evening. "Independent voters want to have a leader who will be positive and upbeat and tone down the partisan rhetoric and get stuff done. That's not what this president has done."
Mr. McDonnell will welcome Mr. Obama to Virginia in Hampton, where the president is scheduled to talk about helping veterans. (Mr. McDonnell and his daughter both served in the Army.) But that official welcome masks an increasing confidence among Republicans about defeating the president in the state next year.
A poll by The Richmond Times-Dispatch released Monday showed that Mr. Obama would face a tight race with either Mitt Romney, the Republican front-runner, or Rick Perry, the governor of Texas (Mr. Romney narrowly led the president 45 percent to 42 percent; and in a matchup with Mr. Perry, he and Mr. Obama were tied at 43 percent).
Jerry Kilgore, a Republican who is a former attorney general in Virginia, said the state's swing voters would probably mirror voters in the rest of the country, especially when it comes to concerns about the economy. The state's unemployment rate is much lower - at 6.2 percent - than in the rest of the nation. But Mr. Kilgore said Virginia voters still feel the economic pain.
"The Northern Virginia demographics continue to be more pro-Democrat," Mr. Kilgore, who is supporting Rick Perry for the Republican nomination, said. "But I think the demographics in Richmond and Hampton Roads are pure swing voters. They will go with the mood of the country."
Democrats in the state disagree that a victory in Virginia is out of reach for the president - though they concede that the race will be a tough one.
Mike Henry, a veteran Democratic strategist who is managing Tim Kaine's United States Senate race next year, said the growth of minorities and suburban votes in the state, as well as the Republican efforts to cut government spending, will help Democrats, including Mr. Obama.
"The environment is harder today in Virginia than it was in 2008. But, there is also huge promise here, and the president can win the state," Mr. Henry said. "The fast growing suburbs are getting better for us, not worse, and the issue menu the Republicans are running on is not helpful to them." 
The pledges to slash the size of the federal government - Ron Paul on Monday proposed cutting spending by 10 percent across the board in a single year - would hit Virginia's many government contractors particularly hard. That could fire up anger at Republican candidates and Republicans in Congress.
And Democrats are counting on shifts in the state's population that helped Mr. Kaine win the governorship in 2005. 
Those include increases in Hispanics, especially in the exurban communities around Northern Virginia, and the movement of traditionally Democratic voters like African-Americans into the suburban rings around the big, Democratic-leaning cities.
That includes places like the Richmond suburbs, which for years were bastions of Republican strength in the state, but which voted for Mr. Kaine and for Mark Warner, a Democrat who is the state's junior senator. Mr. Obama will hold an event in Chesterfield on Tuesday, a Richmond suburb that Republicans have traditionally won.
"I'm glad he's going to Chesterfield because it shows he's not conceding any territory," said Brian Moran, a former state delegate and the chairman of the Virginia Democratic Party. "If the economy starts to turn around, we're obviously very optimistic. As long as it doesn't get any worse, we'll be O.K."
Parts of the state remain extremely difficult for a Democratic presidential candidate. The rural communities in the state's southwest remain bastions of Republicanism. And Democrats have long struggled to win in places where textile factories and tobacco farms have largely disappeared.
Obama campaign officials are counting on the demographic changes to help Mr. Obama's chances in the state. The population centers are shifting inexorably away from the rural communities to the suburban ones. And they note that Mr. Kaine, who served as the chairman of the Democratic National Committee for two years, is continuing to embrace the president in his Senate run.
But it will almost certainly take a huge investment of time and money to secure a victory by the president, much as it did in 2008, when Mr. Obama broke a 40-year streak of victories by Republican presidential candidates in the state.
In 2008, Mr. Obama opened more than 50 campaign offices in communities around the state. And the campaign spent more than $25 million in Virginia. 
"If they do that again, it's going to be very competitive," said one leading Democratic strategist.
It will also require plenty of visits by Mr. Obama. His visit to the state on Tuesday is billed as an official White House trip designed to put pressure on lawmakers to pass his latest proposals to spur job creation in the nation's sluggish economy.
But the trip also serves as a reminder that the president is eager to win in Virginia, even if it's an uphill fight.

HEADLINE: Live Blogging the CNN Debate in Las Vegas

BYLINE: MICHAEL D. SHEAR


HIGHLIGHT: Seven of the Republican candidates for president will gather again tonight for the eighth debate of the year and the first held in the West.&#160; 

 BODY:
Seven of the Republican candidates for president will gather again tonight for the eighth debate of the year and the first held in the West.
The Las Vegas debate, sponsored by and broadcast on CNN, is likely to shine a bright spotlight on Herman Cain, the ex-pizza mogul whose "9-9-9" tax plan has helped rocket him to the top of the recent polls.
But the live, 90-minute event will also be a test of whether Rick Perry can regain his footing after several disappointing debate performances. And it will offer Michele Bachmann another chance to re-emerge as a leader in the contest.
For Mitt Romney, the current front-runner, the debate holds political danger if he fails to meet the expectations he has set in past debates, or if he stumbles under criticism from his rivals.
We'll be providing real-time analysis and fact-checking on our live dashboard, and also taking suggestions from readers for candidate statements that deserve a closer look. You can submit them via Twitter with the hashtag #asknyt or on the dashboard.
Go to the Dashboard
10:59 P.M. | Wrapping Up the Vegas Debate
The debate is done, and so are we. Thanks for following along. 
Read our debate article and come back to The Caucus tomorrow for further analysis. Follow us on Twitter for updates from the 2012 presidential campaign.
- 
10:48 P.M. | Fact Check: Examining Romney's Claim on Illegal Immigrants in Texas
In a tense, at times personal argument over immigration, where Mr. Romney and Mr. Perry repeatedly interrupted and spoke over each other, Mr. Romney charged that the population of illegal immigrants in Texas had increased by 60 percent while Mr. Perry was governor. Mr. Romney said California and Florida, two states that also have large populations of illegal immigrants, had seen no increase in the last 10 years.
It is not clear where Mr. Romney got his figures, but they do not appear to be right. The Pew Hispanic Center, a nonpartisan research group, estimates that the number of illegal immigrants in Texas increased to about 1.6 million in 2010 from 1.1 million in 2000. But the same study found that the number of illegal immigrants in California increased by at least 200,000 in the decade, to 2.5 million from 2.3 million. In Florida, that population saw a big increase, according to the Pew center, to 825,000 in 2010 from 575,000 in 2000. 
In Massachusetts, a much smaller population of illegal immigrants grew to 160,000 in 2010 from 150,000 a decade earlier.
- 
10:41 P.M. | Fact Check: Romney's Texas Jobs Claim
In an attack on Gov. Rick Perry's record on job creation in Texas, Mitt Romney said 40 percent of the jobs created in the state while Mr. Perry was governor went to illegal immigrants.
Mr. Romney was citing a recent study by the Center for Immigration Studies, a conservative-leaning think tank that favors reducing immigration over all. The study, by Steve Camarota, a demographer, found that 81 percent of the jobs created in Texas since 2007 went to recently arrived immigrant workers, including both legal and illegal immigrants. About half of the jobs, or about 40 percent, went to newly arrived illegal immigrants, the study found. 
Governor Perry's campaign says the study is false, arguing essentially that it could not be right because the numbers did not add up. A post on the Perry campaign Web site cites a statistic from the Bureau of Labor Statistics showing that Texas has gained 384,700 jobs since 2007. Department of Homeland Security figures cited by the campaign show that 60,000 illegal immigrants arrived in Texas in that period. That number does not amount to 40 percent of the new jobs. So, Mr. Perry says, the math and the study must be wrong.
- 
10:39 P.M. | Perry and Romney Seem to Make Peace on Faith
Rick Perry went further tonight than he initially did in backing away from controversial remarks about Mitt Romney's Mormon faith made by the Dallas pastor who introduced the Texas governor at a conservative conference earlier this month.
It was an unusual moment of relative comity between Mr. Perry and Mr. Romney, who had tangled during the evening.
Mr. Perry even used the word "apologize," and Mr. Romney seemed to accept it.
Here's the back story:
On Oct. 7, the pastor, Robert Jeffress of Dallas, introduced Mr. Perry at the conference as a "genuine follower of Jesus Christ" - apparently an implicit slap at Mr. Romney - and then made the attack explicit when he walked outside and told reporters that the former Massachusetts governor was in a "cult" and not a Christian.
Within hours, Mr. Perry said he did not agree that the Mormon faith was a cult. 
But asked that day whether the Texas governor agreed or disagreed with Dr. Jeffress that Mr. Romney was not a Christian, a spokesman for the Perry campaign had been more equivocal, saying Mr. Perry "doesn't get into the business of judging other people's hearts or souls. He leaves that to God."
The Perry campaign staffers also did not answer when asked whether they knew when they agreed to a request that Dr. Jeffress make the introduction that the pastor had previously, and very publicly, attacked Mr. Romney's faith. 
But on Tuesday night, Mr. Perry's debate answers seemed simpler and softer, and perhaps even a little contrite.
"I said I did not agree with Pastor Jeffress's remarks, I don't agree with them," said Mr. Perry, who, unlike his campaign spokesman's initial remarks after the incident, did not parse which parts of Dr. Jeffress's statements he was backing away from.
"I can't apologize any more than that," Mr. Perry told the debate audience, and Mr. Romney.
To which Mr. Romney, who had previously called on Mr. Perry to repudiate the remarks, softly said, "Yeah, that's fine."
- 
10:20 P.M. | Trending: 'Libya Is in Africa'
Debates are unforgiving of mistakes. So is Twitter. Just ask Michele Bachmann.
In tonight's debate, she blamed President Obama for putting the United States "in Libya," a reference to the military action that Mr. Obama took in that country.
Then she said Mr. Obama is "now putting us in Africa," an apparent reference to the recent decision to send 100 trainers to help fight the Lord's Resistance Army, a militant group, in Uganda.
The only problem? 
Libya is in Africa, too, something that Mrs. Bachmann either did not know or, at least, misspoke about during the debate.
The result? The phrase "Libya Is in Africa" is trending worldwide on Twitter. Ouch.
- 
10:18 P.M. | Cain Dodges Question on Electrified Fence
Herman Cain appeared to back off - or maybe he just dodged a question about - his on-again off-again suggestion that an electrified fence be built on the border of Mexico. 
But with three flip-flops in as many days, it is anyone's guess how long he stands by his newest statement. 
Here's the day-to-day play-by-play:
On Saturday, Mr. Cain said he would build an electrified fence on the border that could kill those who try to cross illegally. "It's going to be 20 feet high," he said. "It's going to have barbed wire on the top. It's going to be electrified. And there's going to be a sign on the other side saying, 'It will kill you - Warning.' "
On Sunday, he said in a television interview that his comments were meant as "a joke" and "not a serious plan" - despite having sounded quite serious about it the day before. 
On Monday, he told journalists who spoke to him after he met with Joe Arpaio, the staunch anti-immigration sheriff in Phoenix, that he still believed that a border fence was needed "and it might be electrified," according to CBS News. "I'm not walking away from that."
On Tuesday - Day 4 of this particular saga - Mr. Cain told the debate audience that he would "give the serious answer" to a question posed by Anderson Cooper: "So would you build an entire fence along the entire border, and would you have it be electrified?"
But he did not address the question directly.
"Yes, I believe we should secure the border for real," he said. "And it would be a combination of a fence, technology, as well as possibly boots on the ground for some of the more dangerous areas."
- 
9:51 P.M. | Fact Check: Romney and Illegal Immigration
Governor Perry went on the offensive to attack Mr. Romney over an immigration controversy that came to light when Mr. Romney campaigned for president in 2008.
"You hired illegals in your home and you knew about it for a year," Mr. Perry said. 
He said that a year after Mr. Romney first learned that illegal immigrants were taking care of his lawn, those immigrants were still working for him. Mr. Romney's claim that he is tough on illegal immigration is "the height of hypocrisy," Mr. Perry said.
Mr. Romney fired back, "I don't think I've ever hired an illegal immigrant in my life." He gave a long explanation: when he discovered that his landscaping company had sent illegal immigrants to his home for the second time, he fired the company and told the illegal immigrants working at his house to leave.
It isn't clear that Mr. Romney ever knew directly that his landscaping company was using illegal immigrants to tend his lawn. But the episode was embarrassing for Mr. Romney, and it is still awkward now.
The Boston Globe first reported in December 2006 that Mr. Romney was employing a lawn care company that regularly hired illegal immigrants. Mr. Romney said he told an illegal immigrant working on his property to leave but continued to use the same lawn service company. A year later, The Globe reported that the service had once again sent illegal immigrants to Mr. Romney's house in Belmont, Mass. On the same day as the Globe report was published, Mr. Romney fired the company.
At that time, Mr. Romney said he had continued to use the same company because the company had guaranteed that it would not hire any illegal immigrants.
In Tuesday's debate, Mr. Romney said he would combat illegal immigration by adopting a nationwide electronic program to verify the immigration status of all new hires.
- 
9:47 P.M. | Foreign Aid 
Foreign aid represents about 1 percent of America's budget. But don't tell that to the Republican candidates for president, who love to hate it.
All of them indicated that they would slash foreign aid, with Mr. Paul saying he would just end all foreign aid.
Mr. Romney was on the other end of the spectrum, suggesting that some foreign aid was necessary, but acknowledging that the country paid out "too much."
Foreign aid is a frequent subject of conversation with conservative voters, and never more than during an economic downturn.
But none of the candidates pointed out that foreign aid was a tiny share of the national budget.
- 
9:38 P.M. | Fact Check: Border Fence
Is it possible to build a fence along the entire 2,000-mile United States-Mexico border? And if it is, is it worth the cost and would it effectively secure the border? 
Most of the candidates are competing to outdo one another on their support for building a fence - as Mrs. Bachmann has put it - "on every mile, every foot, every inch" of the border. Mr. Cain has called for an electrified fence that could "kill" people, a statement he later said was in jest, then later still said he meant.
Only Mr. Perry, whose state shares 1,200 miles of border, begs to differ about the sense of a hard fence on every mile, without conceding one iota of his own commitment to securing the border. 
It would take 10 to 15 years and cost $30 billion to build a complete fence, Mr. Perry said, arguing that a more cost-effective way is to build a fence in high-traffic areas and to use "boots on the ground" and Predator drones to monitor other areas. "That is the way to shut that border down," he said.
The Department of Homeland Security agrees with Mr. Perry. Officials say that a hard fence is prohibitively costly and inefficient, given that many stretches of the border are in remote mountain areas. To date, according to my colleague Julia Preston, who covers immigration, the department has completed about 650 miles of hard fence, mostly in cities and at points of heavy illegal crossings. Most of that work was done under the Bush administration.
A report in February by the Government Accountability Office found that border authorities, by their own measure, had "operational control" of only 873 miles, or 43 percent, of the border.
Homeland security officials responded that they could either patrol or monitor 81 percent of the border, and that the remaining areas were hostile terrain where illegal crossings are rare.
The Obama administration, with the support of Border Patrol officials, has focused on surveillance technology, equipping the Border Patrol with dozens of fixed remote surveillance systems for busy crossing points and mobile surveillance units for mountainous terrain.
The Center for Immigration Studies, a Washington think tank that seeks to lower immigration, wants more border security but does not favor a fence across the entire border.
(Incidentally, apprehensions by the Border Patrol dropped to 448,000 in 2010, the lowest number since 1972, according to the Department of Homeland Security. The decline under the Obama administration accelerated a drop in border apprehensions that began under President George W. Bush. Since 2005, apprehensions at the Mexican border are down 61 percent.)
That is not stopping most of the Republican candidates from calling for a mile-by-mile fence. Over the weekend, Mrs. Bachmann raised her own bid, signing a pledge to build a "double fence" along the border.
- 
9:31 P.M. | Romney and Faith
Will Mitt Romney's religion - he is a Mormon - be an issue for voters? Should it be? 
That was the question posed to Mr. Romney's rivals, and they tried to carefully walk a fine line in answering.
Mr. Santorum said voters should look at "a candidate's values." Mr. Gingrich insisted that "faith matters," but said, "None of us should rush in judgement of others in the way in which we approach God."
And Rick Perry, who has declined to fully repudiate Robert Jeffress, the Dallas megachurch pastor who has called Mormonism a cult, said politicians need to "stand by our faith." 
But he went further than he has so far to apologize to Mr. Romney for the statements by the pastor, who introduced him at the Values Voter Summit, a conservative conference in Washington, on Oct. 7.
"I have said I didn't agree with that statement," he said.
What's clear is that none of Mr. Romney's rivals are ready to use the issue in the direct way they might use health care or immigration or taxes.
But they may not need to. Mr. Romney, in his answer, said he found it repulsive that "we should choose people based on their religion." He added that he could not abide "the concept that we select people based on the church or synagogue they go to."
For many people, that answer is the right one. But for some conservative Christians - like the pastor - it's possible that the answer could costs him some votes, especially in places like Iowa and South Carolina.
- 
9:26 P.M. | Housing Woes
Housing prices have dropped more steeply in the Las Vegas area than anywhere else in the United States. The price of the average home has fallen 59 percent, according to the S & P/Case-Shiller Home Price Indices. Nevada has a larger share of homes that have been foreclosed on than any other state.
And of course, it's not just a Nevada problem. A growing number of economists regard the collapse of housing prices, and the accompanying loss of wealth, as a central reason that the economy is still growing so slowly. Some of them, including prominent conservatives, have been calling for stronger federal action.
"Failure to act means that further declines in home prices will continue, preventing the rise in consumer spending needed for recovery," Martin Feldstein, an economic adviser to President Ronald Reagan, wrote in a recent opinion piece in The New York Times.
Yet when Anderson Cooper, a debate moderator, asked the Republican candidates what they would do to help homeowners, only two chose to answer the question directly.
Mitt Romney said the government should not address the problem directly, but should instead focus on reviving the economy. "The right course is to let the markets work," he said. "The best thing we can do is to get the economy going."
Mrs. Bachmann expressed empathy for people facing foreclosure. She said President Obama had failed to address the problem. She promised, "I will not fail you on this issue." But she did not offer any ideas, specific or general.
- 
9:20 P.M. | Santorum Mixes It Up
Rick Santorum took his vitamins today. Or maybe he just ate his Wheaties.
Whatever it was, he's been the biggest catalytic force in the debate tonight.
He started the Romney pile-on regarding health care. Like a pit bull, he wouldn't let go.
And now, here he is again, repeatedly accusing his rivals - Mr. Romney, Mr. Cain and Mr. Perry - of supporting the bank bailout known as TARP, the Troubled Asset Relief Program. He said Mr. Perry had written urging action on the day of the TARP vote.
Mr. Perry interrupted, saying that wasn't true. He said the letter only urged action on the bailout bill, not passage. 
But Mr. Santorum wouldn't give up. What else was he talking about if not passage? an aggressive Mr. Santorum asked. 
A former senator from Pennsylvania, Mr. Santorum sometimes comes across as a mild-mannered politician who cares about families and social issues. To date, he has made little impact on the race, has raised little money and is stuck near the bottom of the polls. 
But his performance in the debate tonight has served to mix things up more than in any previous debate.
That might help him gain attention in the next several days. But it also could serve the purposes of Mr. Perry and Mr. Romney, both of whom are probably eager to see each other attacked by someone else.
- 
9:09 P.M. | Fact Check: A Model Plan? 
Another Republican presidential debate, another attack on Mitt Romney for the health care plan that was the centerpiece of his tenure as Massachusetts governor but has since emerged as the most frequent point of attack for his Republican rivals.
Tonight the attack came from Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who criticized Mr. Romney for the plan and said it was the basis of President Obama's health care plan, more commonly known among Republicans as "Obamacare."
Mr. Romney punched back, suggesting that he never thought his plan would or should be a model for a national program to expand health insurance.
Mr. Romney said that during the 2008 campaign, "I was asked: 'Is this something that you would have the whole nation do?' And I said: 'No; this is something that was crafted for Massachusetts. It would be wrong to adopt this as a nation.' "
Not exactly. Mr. Romney has repeatedly suggested that he believed that the Massachusetts program - and in particular its mandate for individuals to purchase health insurance plans - would be a good model for the rest of the country.
During an appearance on "Meet the Press" in December 2007, Mr. Romney said that while he did believed that every state would face different circumstances, his program was "a good model for other states."
"I think it's a good model for other states. Maybe not every state but most, and so what I'd do at the federal level is give every state the same kind of flexibility we got from the federal government as well as some carrots and sticks to actually get all their citizens insured. And I think a lot of states will choose what we did."
Mr. Romney added that he would not want a policy that would force other states to adopt the Massachusetts model - which Mr. Obama's health care bill, in some sense, does - but suggested that other states should consider the mandate.
"So if a state chose a mandate, it wouldn't bother you?" asked the host, Tim Russert.
"I'd think it's a terrific idea," Mr. Romney answered. "I think you're going to find when it's all said and done, after all these states that are the laboratories of democracy get their chance to try their own plans, those who follow the path that we pursued will find it's the best path, and we'll end up with a nation that's taken a mandate approach."
- 
9:08 P.M. | Bachmann on Cost of Financial Regulation
On what basis does Bachmann claim that [financial] regulation costs $1.8 trillion? #asknyt
ECONPROF, New York
Mrs. Bachmann is referring to a 2010 study by economists at Lafayette College that was sponsored by the office of advocacy at the Small Business Administration.
- 
8:56 P.M. | Perry's Strategy - Be Aggressive
When "Saturday Night Live" mocks you for falling asleep at a debate, you do something.
If you're Rick Perry, you come out blazing, launching a direct, personal attack on your chief rival and repeatedly interrupting to accuse him of lying to the American people.
The exchanges between Mr. Perry and Mr. Romney clearly show the agenda that the Texas governor had coming into the debate: be really aggressive.
But a politician can sometimes take a strategy too far. When Mr. Perry returned to the issue of Mr. Romney's hiring of illegal immigrants a second time, the audience booed.
There's still more than 30 minutes left. Plenty of time for more clashes.
- 
8:51 P.M. | Perry vs. Romney on Immigration
Governor Perry, asked about the uninsured in Texas, shifted gears entirely to attack Mr. Romney on immigration, and on allegations that Mr. Romney's family hired a lawn service that employed illegal immigrants.
"You stood here and did not tell the truth that you had illegals working on your property," Mr. Perry said. "The idea you can talk about any of us having an immigration issue is beyond me." 
Mr. Romney went right back on the offense, accusing Mr. Perry of opposing a fence along the United States-Mexican border and of supporting amnesty for illegal immigrants. This led right into a shouting match, with Mr. Perry saying Mr. Romney was the only one who'd supported amnesty.
"This has been a rough couple of debates for Rick," Mr. Romney said, as if in explanation. "You have a problem with allowing someone to finish speaking." 
- 
8:43 P.M. | Hitting Hard on Health Care 
If Mitt Romney thought he could skate above the fray in these debates, he found out quickly tonight that his rivals won't let him.
Led by a furiously intense Mr. Santorum, Mr. Romney's rivals took direct aim once again at Mr. Romney's Massachusetts health care plan.
Mr. Santorum called it "top-down government-run health care," and Mr. Gingrich added that it was "one more big-government, bureaucratic, high-cost system."
For the first time in the debates, Mr. Romney looked a bit rattled, and on the defensive. He tried to argue that his plan was different from President Obama's health care plans. And he tried to explain the motivations for enacting the plan in his state.
But his rivals were having none of it. They interrupted him. They shook their heads and rolled their eyes. It was clear that they were not going to let him off the hook.
And when Mr. Romney told Mr. Gingrich that he came up with the individual mandate for his health care plan from Mr. Gingrich, the former House speaker, himself, Mr. Gingrich was insistent: "You did not get that from me."
In fact, as he then admitted, Mr. Gingrich did support an individual mandate. Score one for Mr. Romney. But at the end of the long exchange, it became clear that Mr. Romney's rivals are eager to go after what they see as his soft underbelly.
- 
8:34 P.M. | Cain Taking Heat from the Field
Herman Cain has discovered what it's like to be in the top tier of the presidential contest.
Within moments of the CNN debate opening - spurred by an audience question about a national sales tax - his rivals pounced, politely praising him even as they did.
Mr. Romney said he liked Mr. Cain's chutzpah. Rick Perry said, "I love you, brother." Rick Santorum said, "I love his boldness." 
But they also described Mr. Cain's 9-9-9 plan as a terrible idea that would increase taxes for the middle class and would become a tool for the federal government to increase taxes even further over time.
Mr. Santorum called it "major increases in taxes on people." Mr. Perry added, "Let me tell you something: you don't have to have a big analysis to figure this one out." He said it would not work.
Mr. Cain resisted, saying he had been attacked. "That simply is not true. I invite people to look at our analysis," Mr. Cain said. "I invite every American to do their own math."
But it is clear that the Republican candidates are eager to knock Mr. Cain down a peg or two, especially given the quick rise in the national polls that Mr. Cain has experienced in the last several days.
Asked after several minutes of the criticism why he thought Mr. Cain's plan would be a harder sell to the American people, Newt Gingrich said, "You just watched it."
- 
8:30 P.M. | Fact Check: A Deeper Look at 9-9-9
Herman Cain said his much-discussed "9-9-9" plan "does not raise taxes on those that are making the least. It's simply not true."
But that is exactly what a growing number of independent analysts have concluded.
The plan calls for deep cuts in the existing federal taxes on individual and corporate income, both of which would be reduced to a flat rate of 9 percent from a system of tiered rates that run above 30 percent for the highest earners. Mr. Cain then proposes the addition of a 9 percent tax on sales.
Analysts say Mr. Cain's plan would raise taxes for lower-income families, while reducing the taxes paid by higher-income families.
"Herman Cain's 9-9-9 plan is a terrific example of fiscal hocus-pocus," Edward D. Kleinbard, a law professor at the University of Southern California, writes in a coming analysis of the plan for the trade journal Tax Notes. "It is presented as a low-tax panacea, but it actually would raise the tax bills of many Americans very substantially."
Professor Kleinbard estimated that a family with $120,000 in 2010 income would have paid $541 less in federal taxes under Mr. Cain's plan. A family that earned $50,000, by contrast, would have paid $4,800 more.
The Tax Policy Center, a joint venture of the Urban Institute and the Brookings Institute, concluded that the plan amounted to a 25.38 percent national sales tax. Flat sales taxes fall more heavily on lower-income families, siphoning off a much larger share of their total income.
It is also important to note that the 9-9-9 plan is only a transitional stage in Mr. Cain's broader plan to overhaul federal taxation. He has proposed the ultimate elimination of income taxes, in favor of a flat 30 percent sales tax.
- 
8:24 P.M. | 'Bump Plans' 
Rick Perry is clearly sick of being told that he's not enough of an attack dog out there. Moments into the Las Vegas debate, he took the opportunity to swipe at Mr. Romney in his introduction, calling himself "an authentic conservative, not a conservative of convenience." Then, in the first question - on Herman Cain's 9-9-9 plan - Mr. Perry came out swinging, telling Mr. Cain that it was a complete no-go in states like New Hampshire that have no sales tax, and switching gears to pitch his own jobs plan, the second half of which will be released next week in South Carolina.
"I'll bump plans with you, brother, and we'll see who has the best idea about how to get this country working again," Mr. Perry said.
- 
8:14 P.M. | Perry Comes Out Swinging
Well, that didn't take long.
Rick Perry, the governor of Texas, decided to use his two-sentence introduction to take the first shot of the night, at Mitt Romney.
Mr. Perry declared himself to be a "proven job creator" and then said he was "an authentic conservative, not a conservative of convenience."
That was clearly directed at Mr. Romney, who may be Mr. Perry's chief rival for the Republican nomination. Mr. Perry has made it clear that he intends to attack Mr. Romney as not being a true conservative. 
Expect more to come.
- 
7:32 P.M. | A Pre-Debate Guide to Post-Debate Spin
If a presidential campaign is a test of a candidate's ability to govern, the moments immediately after a presidential debate measure a campaign's ability to twist, manipulate, cajole and spin members of the press.
In a few hours, tonight's debate will be over and reporters attending the debate will flock to a nearby room where campaign surrogates - and sometimes the candidate - will explain away gaffes and strategically emphasize the good moments.
Here's a pre-debate look at the post-debate spin process from the Caucus blog.
Spin Recycle: What the Post-Debate Debate Might Be
- 
7:11 P.M. | Obama Campaign Offers New Twist to an Old Game
Remember that college drinking game? The one where you'd all gather together to watch a movie, and every time a certain word was uttered, everyone would drink? 
Well, Obama for America clearly remembers, and it's got an interesting twist on the old game.
A new Web site - G.O.P. Debate Watch - invites supporters of President Obama to pick from a series of words or phrases that are likely to be uttered during tonight's debate.
The words are: "Obamacare," "9-9-9," "(de)regulation," "Romneycare," "repeal," "amnesty," "fence," "socialism" and "class warfare."
Supporters can then pick a donation amount -from $5 to $50 or anything else - and every time their word gets uttered, their credit card will be charged that amount.
"Tomorrow, after the debate is over and a final tally of words has been calculated, your card will be charged and you'll receive an email confirmation of how much you've contributed," the Web site says.
And it adds the following warning: "Joining us late in the game? Please be aware that you'll be charged for words used since the beginning of tonight's debate."
- 
4:46 P.M. | Republicans Go 'All In' for Vegas Debate
Seven of the Republican candidates for president will gather again tonight for the eighth debate of the year and the first held in the West. 
The Las Vegas debate, sponsored by and broadcast on CNN, is likely to shine a bright spotlight on Herman Cain, the ex-pizza mogul whose "9-9-9" tax plan has helped rocket him to the top of the recent polls.
But the live, 90-minute event will also be a test of whether Rick Perry can regain his footing after several disappointing debate performances. And it will offer Michele Bachmann another chance to re-emerge as a leader in the contest.
For Mitt Romney, the current front-runner, the debate holds political danger if he fails to meet the expectations he has set in past debates, or if he stumbles under criticism from his rivals.

(The Caucus)

PUB-DATE: October 18, 2011

SECTION: US; politics

LENGTH: 1737 words

HEADLINE: Las Vegas Debate Fact Check

BYLINE: THE NEW YORK TIMES


HIGHLIGHT: New York Times reporters examine statements from candidates in the Republican field on immigration, the economy, foreign policy and health care. 

 BODY:
PREV

        

Ethan Miller/Getty Images
        

Ethan Miller/Getty Images
        

Monica Almeida/The New York Times
        

Paul Buck/European Pressphoto Agency
        

Monica Almeida/The New York Times
        

Monica Almeida/The New York Times
        

Monica Almeida/The New York Times

NEXT
Mitt Romney and Gov. Rick Perry in one of many heated exchanges.
Romney's Texas Jobs Claim
In an attack on Gov. Rick Perry's record on job creation in Texas, Mitt Romney said 40 percent of the jobs created in the state while Mr. Perry was governor went to illegal immigrants.
Mr. Romney was citing a recent study by the Center for Immigration Studies, a conservative-leaning think tank that favors reducing immigration over all. The study, by Steve Camarota, a demographer, found that 81 percent of the jobs created in Texas since 2007 went to recently arrived immigrant workers, including both legal and illegal immigrants. About half of the jobs, or about 40 percent, went to newly arrived illegal immigrants, the study found. 
Governor Perry's campaign says the study is false, arguing essentially that it could not be right because the numbers did not add up. A post on the Perry campaign Web site cites a statistic from the Bureau of Labor Statistics showing that Texas has gained 384,700 jobs since 2007. Department of Homeland Security figures cited by the campaign show that 60,000 illegal immigrants arrived in Texas in that period. That number does not amount to 40 percent of the new jobs. So, Mr. Perry says, the math and the study must be wrong.
- 
Romney and Illegal Immigration
Governor Perry went on the offensive to attack Mr. Romney over an immigration controversy that came to light when Mr. Romney campaigned for president in 2008.
"You hired illegals in your home and you knew about it for a year," Mr. Perry said. 
He said that a year after Mr. Romney first learned that illegal immigrants were taking care of his lawn, those immigrants were still working for him. Mr. Romney's claim that he is tough on illegal immigration is "the height of hypocrisy," Mr. Perry said.
Mr. Romney fired back, "I don't think I've ever hired an illegal immigrant in my life." He gave a long explanation: when he discovered that his landscaping company had sent illegal immigrants to his home for the second time, he fired the company and told the illegal immigrants working at his house to leave.
It isn't clear that Mr. Romney ever knew directly that his landscaping company was using illegal immigrants to tend his lawn. But the episode was embarrassing for Mr. Romney, and it is still awkward now.
The Boston Globe first reported in December 2006 that Mr. Romney was employing a lawn care company that regularly hired illegal immigrants. Mr. Romney said he told an illegal immigrant working on his property to leave but continued to use the same lawn service company. A year later, The Globe reported that the service had once again sent illegal immigrants to Mr. Romney's house in Belmont, Mass. On the same day as the Globe report was published, Mr. Romney fired the company.
At that time, Mr. Romney said he had continued to use the same company because the company had guaranteed that it would not hire any illegal immigrants.
In Tuesday's debate, Mr. Romney said he would combat illegal immigration by adopting a nationwide electronic program to verify the immigration status of all new hires.
- 
Border Fence
Is it possible to build a fence along the entire 2,000-mile United States-Mexico border? And if it is, is it worth the cost and would it effectively secure the border? 
Most of the candidates are competing to outdo one another on their support for building a fence -- as Mrs. Bachmann has put it -- "on every mile, every foot, every inch" of the border. Mr. Cain has called for an electrified fence that could "kill" people, a statement he later said was in jest, then later still said he meant.
Only Mr. Perry, whose state shares 1,200 miles of border, begs to differ about the sense of a hard fence on every mile, without conceding one iota of his own commitment to securing the border. 
It would take 10 to 15 years and cost $30 billion to build a complete fence, Mr. Perry said, arguing that a more cost-effective way is to build a fence in high-traffic areas and to use "boots on the ground" and Predator drones to monitor other areas. "That is the way to shut that border down," he said.
The Department of Homeland Security agrees with Mr. Perry. Officials say that a hard fence is prohibitively costly and inefficient, given that many stretches of the border are in remote mountain areas. To date, according to my colleague Julia Preston, who covers immigration, the department has completed about 650 miles of hard fence, mostly in cities and at points of heavy illegal crossings. Most of that work was done under the Bush administration.
A report in February by the Government Accountability Office found that border authorities, by their own measure, had "operational control" of only 873 miles, or 43 percent, of the border.
Homeland security officials responded that they could either patrol or monitor 81 percent of the border, and that the remaining areas were hostile terrain where illegal crossings are rare.
The Obama administration, with the support of Border Patrol officials, has focused on surveillance technology, equipping the Border Patrol with dozens of fixed remote surveillance systems for busy crossing points and mobile surveillance units for mountainous terrain.
The Center for Immigration Studies, a Washington think tank that seeks to lower immigration, wants more border security but does not favor a fence across the entire border.
(Incidentally, apprehensions by the Border Patrol dropped to 448,000 in 2010, the lowest number since 1972, according to the Department of Homeland Security. The decline under the Obama administration accelerated a drop in border apprehensions that began under President George W. Bush. Since 2005, apprehensions at the Mexican border are down 61 percent.)
That is not stopping most of the Republican candidates from calling for a mile-by-mile fence. Over the weekend, Mrs. Bachmann raised her own bid, signing a pledge to build a "double fence" along the border.
- 
A Model Plan? 
Another Republican presidential debate, another attack on Mitt Romney for the health care plan that was the centerpiece of his tenure as Massachusetts governor but has since emerged as the most frequent point of attack for his Republican rivals.
Tonight the attack came from Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who criticized Mr. Romney for the plan and said it was the basis of President Obama's health care plan, more commonly known among Republicans as "Obamacare."
Mr. Romney punched back, suggesting that he never thought his plan would or should be a model for a national program to expand health insurance.
Mr. Romney said that during the 2008 campaign, "I was asked: 'Is this something that you would have the whole nation do?' And I said: 'No; this is something that was crafted for Massachusetts. It would be wrong to adopt this as a nation.' "
Not exactly. Mr. Romney has repeatedly suggested that he believed that the Massachusetts program -- and in particular its mandate for individuals to purchase health insurance plans -- would be a good model for the rest of the country.
During an appearance on "Meet the Press" in December 2007, Mr. Romney said that while he did believed that every state would face different circumstances, his program was "a good model for other states."
"I think it's a good model for other states. Maybe not every state but most, and so what I'd do at the federal level is give every state the same kind of flexibility we got from the federal government as well as some carrots and sticks to actually get all their citizens insured. And I think a lot of states will choose what we did."
Mr. Romney added that he would not want a policy that would force other states to adopt the Massachusetts model -- which Mr. Obama's health care bill, in some sense, does -- but suggested that other states should consider the mandate.
"So if a state chose a mandate, it wouldn't bother you?" asked the host, Tim Russert.
"I'd think it's a terrific idea," Mr. Romney answered. "I think you're going to find when it's all said and done, after all these states that are the laboratories of democracy get their chance to try their own plans, those who follow the path that we pursued will find it's the best path, and we'll end up with a nation that's taken a mandate approach."
- 
A Deeper Look at 9-9-9
Herman Cain said his much-discussed "9-9-9" plan "does not raise taxes on those that are making the least. It's simply not true."
But that is exactly what a growing number of independent analysts have concluded.
The plan calls for deep cuts in the existing federal taxes on individual and corporate income, both of which would be reduced to a flat rate of 9 percent from a system of tiered rates that run above 30 percent for the highest earners. Mr. Cain then proposes the addition of a 9 percent tax on sales.
Analysts say Mr. Cain's plan would raise taxes for lower-income families, while reducing the taxes paid by higher-income families.
"Herman Cain's 9-9-9 plan is a terrific example of fiscal hocus-pocus," Edward D. Kleinbard, a law professor at the University of Southern California, writes in a coming analysis of the plan for the trade journal Tax Notes. "It is presented as a low-tax panacea, but it actually would raise the tax bills of many Americans very substantially."
Professor Kleinbard estimated that a family with $120,000 in 2010 income would have paid $541 less in federal taxes under Mr. Cain's plan. A family that earned $50,000, by contrast, would have paid $4,800 more.
The Tax Policy Center, a joint venture of the Urban Institute and the Brookings Institute, concluded that the plan amounted to a 25.38 percent national sales tax. Flat sales taxes fall more heavily on lower-income families, siphoning off a much larger share of their total income.
It is also important to note that the 9-9-9 plan is only a transitional stage in Mr. Cain's broader plan to overhaul federal taxation. He has proposed the ultimate elimination of income taxes, in favor of a flat 30 percent sales tax.

HEADLINE: Protests Are a Payday for Security Firms

BYLINE: By KEVIN ROOSE

 BODY:
They call when they make the Forbes 400 list. They call when annual hedge fund rankings appear, when their names are mentioned on CNBC and when their children travel abroad. And, these days, they call when protesters camped in Lower Manhattan grow uncomfortable with the idea of their existence.
The ultra-rich bankers, hedge fund managers and private equity executives of New York City have long enlisted private security firms to help safeguard them and their wealth. But as the mood on Main Street turns increasingly hostile, New York's financial titans are cranking their security measures up to 11. For the high-end security firms that provide the moneyed elite with specialty services like around-the-clock bodyguards and elaborate home security systems, Occupy Wall Street has been a stimulus package all its own.
''We expect to more than double our revenue in New York this year,'' said Paul M. Viollis, a co-founder of Risk Control Strategies, a firm that protects some of the top executives on Wall Street.
Another company, Insite Security, has gotten dozens of calls since the protests began and expects to increase its revenue at least 40 percent this year, according to Christopher Falkenberg, its chief executive. (In accordance with the industry's code of secrecy, none of the security experts interviewed for this article provided client names.) 
Executive protection, as the guard-the-rich industry is known, got an initial jolt from the financial crisis of 2008. Lloyd C. Blankfein, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, got permission from a local review board to build a six-foot-high security gate outside his Hamptons house in April 2008, the month after Bear Stearns collapsed. Lehman Brothers, another crisis casualty, had a bomb-sniffing Labrador retriever named Bella stationed at its headquarters. And in 2010, when the activist group the Yes Men encouraged its supporters to perform citizens' arrests on John A. Paulson, the billionaire hedge fund manager, Mr. Paulson's firm hired additional security guards to combat the threat, according to a person with knowledge of the decision. A spokesman for Mr. Paulson declined to comment.
But the most recent round of Main Street rage has raised the risk factor. Last week, when protesters picketed the homes of some of Manhattan's richest residents, they made a stop at Mr. Paulson's mansion, as well as the homes of Jamie Dimon, the chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, and Stephen A. Schwarzman, the billionaire co-founder of the Blackstone Group. One sign carried by protesters depicted Mr. Blankfein's severed head on a stake.
Scenes like these are causing executives to supplement their internal security teams with the services of outside specialty firms. A chief financial officer of a major bank recently called Risk Control Strategies with the news that he had received a menacing e-mail from an anonymous sender.
''You filled your pockets, and now I'm going to fill mine, starting with your family,'' the e-mail said, according to Mr. Viollis. The firm quickly dispatched a pair of guards to the client's house.
Another client, a C-suite executive at a large Wall Street firm, recently asked Mr. Viollis to send undercover agents to Zuccotti Park to find out if the protesters were planning to harm him or his colleagues. (Mr. Viollis said he would probably decline the request.)
But as versions of Occupy Wall Street fan out across the country, even executives who aren't recognizable to the general public are worried.
''If Zuccotti Park is tapping into resentment against wealthy people, that really changes the calculus,'' said Mr. Falkenberg, a former Secret Service agent. ''It's not that far of a connection between what's happening now in that park and a more focused, research-based kind of attack.''
The executive protection industry has existed as long as there have been executives, but it got a boost in 2003, when Edward S. Lampert, a Greenwich hedge fund manager, was kidnapped by four men on his way to his car. The men stuffed the billionaire into a Ford Expedition at gunpoint, took him to a motel and tied him up in the bathroom for two days. (Mr. Lampert survived the incident, and his kidnappers were caught and convicted.)
These days, bankers and hedge fund managers are willing to spend millions of dollars to avoid enduring anything similar.
''Typically, what happens is that these guys wake up one day, look around, and say, 'Wow, I've really provided some great benefits for my family, and boy, it looks like I've also introduced a modicum of risk,' '' said Mr. Viollis. ''Then they call me.''
The first step in securing an executive is building what is known as a risk profile. Security experts -- typically retired detectives, C.I.A. agents and military veterans -- conduct surveillance on a client and pick out every point of vulnerability. Does she eat at the same deli every Wednesday? Does he park his car in a spot labeled with his name? Are his children's Facebook profiles filled with photos of the family's vacation house? They then present the client with a list of the habits that could present an opportunity for thieves or kidnappers.
''People think security is having a 300-pound bald guy named Tiny following you,'' Mr. Falkenberg said. ''In reality, it's a lot more complicated than that.''
After the risk profile is complete, firms begin fortifying the client's life, starting at home, using a cornucopia of high-tech gadgets. There are biometric door locks that read palm prints, infrared cameras that can spot potential intruders in total darkness and in-ground sensors that can detect motion around a home's perimeter and immediately transmit data to a dispatcher.
''Now, instead of having a retired cop sitting in the garage on Maiden Lane, you have a whole command center at your disposal,'' said Robert S. Tucker, the chief executive of T.& M. Protection.
International travel, a staple of bank executive life, is among the biggest security hazards. In the downtown offices of Risk Control Strategies, a wall-mounted computer monitor displays a map of the world overlaid with blinking icons denoting security risks. There is an icon for hazardous materials, an icon for riots and civil disobedience and an icon indicating instances of cyber-hacking. Traveling executives are often given profiles of dangerous neighborhoods, and some are equipped with armored town cars.
As anxiety has rippled through the gilded class, a cottage industry has sprouted to protect high-net-worth individuals from every threat imaginable. There are companies that sell kidnapping insurance, companies that will run background checks on domestic staff members, companies that will replace glass windows with bulletproof polycarbonate panels and companies that will build safe rooms with steel-fortified walls.
Many of the latest technological advances in the executive protection industry are ''technical surveillance countermeasures,'' sensors that can sweep homes, offices, hotel rooms and cars for electronic spying devices. Mr. Viollis estimates that his business in that area has tripled this year, largely because of an influx of hedge fund managers who believe they may be the targets of an investigation and financial executives worried about the theft of trade secrets by competitors.
All these provisions come at a startling cost. Just one highly trained bodyguard -- ''personal protection professional,'' in the industry parlance -- can run $200 an hour, and a full-time driver can cost an executive $150,000 per year. A thorough sweep for surveillance can cost $1.25 per square foot of space and a full-home surveillance system can run anywhere from $100,000 to $1.5 million.
Even where paranoia is a cardinal virtue, there are those who seem to take caution too far. One executive contacted Insite requesting help planning his escape from the United States in the event the federal government was overthrown, said Howard A. Shapiro, Insite's chief technology officer. The executive wanted to know how much gold to keep on hand and how to escape the United States by submarine in the event of a major incident.
''He was spending the majority of his wealth on security,'' Mr. Shapiro said. ''We don't encourage that.''
But when personalized security programs work, they can turn life-threatening situations into mere blips on the radar.
Late last year, Gertrude Boyle, the 86-year-old chairwoman of Columbia Sportswear, came home to find a man waiting in her driveway, asking her to sign a book for him. When Ms. Boyle refused, the man pulled a gun and demanded a large ransom payment. Ms. Boyle calmly told the gunman she had to disable her home security system before letting him into her house, and surreptitiously pressed a panic button that summoned the police. Officers arrived within minutes, and Ms. Boyle escaped unharmed.
In a turbulent age for Wall Street's power brokers, that kind of security has no price tag. ''You can never protect someone 100 percent,'' said Mr. Viollis, his face illuminated by the glowing icons on the global threat map in his office. ''But you can get close.''

HEADLINE: Lawsuit Seeks Release of Police Commissioner's Schedule

BYLINE: By AL BAKER

 BODY:
A civil liberties group filed a lawsuit on Tuesday seeking to force the New York Police Department to release the daily schedules of Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly.
The lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan by the New York Civil Liberties Union, characterized Mr. Kelly as ''the most important appointed'' official in city government, and said that details of whom he meets with remained largely shrouded in secrecy. 
Other high-placed officials, including the president, publicly disclose portions of their schedules, the suit said, and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo last month began posting a detailed version of his daily schedules online.
''There is no good reason for Commissioner Kelly to withhold this information from the public,'' Donna Lieberman, the executive director of the civil liberties group, said in a statement. ''If it's safe for the leader of the country to disclose his schedule, then it's safe for the N.Y.P.D. commissioner to do the same.''
The 10-page lawsuit, which seeks details of Mr. Kelly's appointments dating to January 2002, when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg tapped him for a second stint as police commissioner, was filed on behalf of Leonard Levitt, a former Newsday reporter who now writes a blog about law enforcement matters on his Web site, NYPD Confidential.
Mr. Levitt first requested copies of Mr. Kelly's schedule in February, under the state's Freedom of Information Law, four months after reporting last October on Mr. Kelly's habit of entertaining guests at the Harvard Club, in Midtown. Though some of his expenses at the club, including the annual dues, were paid for by the New York City Police Foundation, neither the foundation nor a spokesman for Mr. Kelly would say whom the commissioner had entertained at the club.
After the Police Department denied Mr. Levitt's request in May, the civil liberties group appealed it. But a month later, the department denied that appeal, ''asserting that disclosing Commissioner Kelly's schedule over the past decade would endanger both the commissioner and the people with whom he met,'' according to a statement from the civil liberties group.
But the lawsuit pointed out that certain information from Mr. Kelly's appointments could be redacted if it presented a security threat to Mr. Kelly or anyone else. ''The department has no authority, however, to categorically withhold the entire schedule,'' the suit said.
Paul J. Browne, the department's chief spokesman, declined to comment on the suit.
Mitchell L. Moss, a professor of urban policy and planning at New York University, said there was no provision in the City Charter mandating the disclosure of city commissioners' public schedules. He said a police commissioner should get ''broad latitude'' in a post-terrorist era.
''The police commissioner of New York City occupies a special, appointed position,'' Mr. Moss said. ''He's our secretary of defense, head of the C.I.A. and, I would say, chief architect rolled into one. He may be the one person who we should treat with some respect on his privacy.''
Invoking the television series ''24,'' Mr. Moss added of Mr. Kelly, ''He's as close as we come to Jack Bauer.''
