HEADLINE: Two Major Hospital Groups In City Explore a Partnership

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

 BODY:
Two of New York City's major hospital organizations are exploring a partnership that would give them a large share of the city's patients and make them a formidable rival for other city hospitals in tough economic times.
A partnership between the institutions, Continuum Health Partners and NYU Langone Medical Center, could alter the balance of power in New York City health care for a generation. It could also complicate efforts to control health care costs: with reduced competition, the hospitals would gain clout in negotiating rates with insurance companies, potentially driving up costs for employers and employees across the region. 
Executives at both organizations confirmed the partnership discussions on Thursday, while saying that they were still preliminary and that the details of how such a relationship would be structured -- whether it would be a merger or short of that -- remained to be worked out.
''This is an opportunity from our perspective,'' Stanley Brezenoff, chief executive of Continuum, said. ''There is sort of a shared view of the potential that this kind of strategic alliance or collaboration could have.''
Continuum runs Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan, an East Side competitor of NYU Langone; St. Luke's and Roosevelt Hospitals and the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary in Manhattan; and a branch of Beth Israel in Brooklyn.
The proposed partnership reflects a larger trend in the industry to create bigger entities -- often comprising hospitals, physician practices and community health care centers -- in anticipation of changes in state and federal health care policy. Under the new policies the networks will be paid by the government for meeting certain standards of performance, like reducing readmissions and keeping costs down.
''There is a large-scale movement in anticipation of health care reform, where size becomes more and more important,'' said Mukesh Gangwal, managing director of Huron Healthcare, a hospital consulting firm.
Manhattan hospitals have been slowly consolidating for years, with New York-Presbyterian and Continuum becoming prominent.
More recently, North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health Systemtook over Lenox Hill Hospital on the Upper East Side and was chosen to run a scaled-down version of St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan in Greenwich Village, which went bankrupt and closed last year. Some St. Vincent's doctors said one reason the hospital failed was that it did not have the leverage of the chain hospitals to negotiate higher payments from insurers.
Advocates for patients reacted warily to the new proposal.
Nisha Agarwal, director of the health justice program for New York Lawyers for the Public Interest, a nonprofit civil-rights law firm, said Thursday that she would worry about Continuum's becoming more like NYU.
''NYU is virtually inaccessible to low-income and uninsured patients,'' Ms. Agarwal said. ''If that is the direction the new behemoth goes, it would be very bad for consumers.''
Many NYU doctors care for poor patients at nearby Bellevue Hospital Center, which is part of the city's public hospital system and which has a contract with NYU.
Mark Wagar, president of Empire BlueCross BlueShield, said he did not think a partnership would be bad for the insurance industry or consumers. ''I doubt very seriously and it would be a big mistake to make a merger to negotiate for more money, because it's a zero-sum game,'' Mr. Wagar said.
The State Health Department is aware of the talks, but will not get involved until there are more details that could require state approval, said Jeffrey Gordon, a department spokesman.
Mr. Brezenoff said Continuum was in the black and would bring its market share to the table: it has 26 percent of all inpatients discharged by Manhattan hospitals. NYU has a smaller share, executives said, although they could not provide an exact figure, but it draws from a wider geographic area, including some foreign patients. Continuum has an operating budget of about $2.5 billion, and NYU of about $2.7 billion.
''We're doing gangbusters at Beth Israel,'' in part because it has absorbed patients from the closing of St. Vincent's, Mr. Brezenoff said. ''We think exploring a partnership makes sense for us at this moment of strength.''
Anthony Shorris, chief of staff, vice dean and senior vice president of NYU Langone Medical Center, said there would be ''a lot of complementarity'' in an alliance of the hospital groups.
''One of the things everyone realizes is we're going to have to rationalize the delivery of health care in the country and everywhere else,'' Mr. Shorris said.
Continuum's hospitals provide much basic care, including obstetrics and emergency care, Mr. Brezenoff said. NYU, with its medical school and research as well as Tisch Hospital, the Hospital for Joint Diseases and the Rusk Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine, has strong programs in high-level medicine like transplants and microsurgery.
Mr. Brezenoff agreed that federal and state policy changes played a role. ''We have a fair amount of government-paid patients; Medicaid is in everybody's cross hairs in New York State,'' he said. ''There are provisions already in legislation that go to reshaping the models of health care delivery.''

HEADLINE: Times Co. Reports a Profit, Aided by Digital Subscribers

BYLINE: By JEREMY W. PETERS

 BODY:
The New York Times Company continued to attract paying subscribers to its flagship Web site in the third quarter, bolstering a new revenue stream that has helped offset a decline in advertising revenue.
The company, which reported its earnings for July through September on Thursday, posted a profit of $15.7 million, compared with a loss of $4.3 million during the third quarter last year. That translated to earnings of 10 cents a diluted share versus a loss of 3 cents a share a year ago.
Costs decreased during the quarter, falling 3.6 percent to $504.2 million. Circulation revenue grew by 3.4 percent to $237 million. 
Total advertising revenue, meanwhile, slipped 8.8 percent, to $262 million, as national and classified advertising and the company's About.com group proved particularly weak. Revenue in every advertising category was down, a sign of the challenges the industry faces in a stagnant economy.
And in a further sign of the financial uncertainty newspapers are facing, overall digital revenue, which has typically posted double-digit growth, fell 4.5 percent, to $74.8 million. That decline, in part, is because of weakness at About, which once was an engine of growth at the company but is now suffering from a change in the way Google directs traffic to informational sites.
Digital revenue at Times Company newspapers increased, but at a rate of only 6.2 percent to $50.3 million.
The company said it did not see any reason to be concerned about the overall strength of its digital advertising business in those numbers, calling it a lull that it hoped to reverse once the economy picked up.
''As the economy has gotten more squirrely, advertisers are pulling back a little bit,'' said Martin A. Nisenholtz, senior vice president for digital operations at the Times Company. ''We don't think there's anything fundamental about that. It's just simply a question of some of the very significant economic issues that have faced us.''
The company benefited from a $65.3 million pretax gain from the sale of part of its stake in the Fenway Sports Group, which owns the Boston Red Sox. It also recorded a $46.4 million charge related to a repayment of the $250 million it borrowed from the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Helu. The repayment in August came three and a half years before it was due.
Operating profit for the quarter was $33 million, compared with $9 million a year ago. Excluding special items, operating profit grew 5.5 percent, to $65.5 million.
In the most closely watched metric of The Times's well being -- its new online subscription business -- the company reported continued growth. The Times now has 324,000 paid subscribers to the various digital editions of the paper, including e-readers and its Web site, compared with 281,000 at the end of the second quarter. Those figures do not include the 100,000 users who receive access to NYTimes.com free through a sponsorship by the Ford Motor Company.
One key question about the success of The Times's digital strategy -- whether subscribers would renew at full price once their low introductory rates expired -- was answered in part on Thursday. Janet L. Robinson, president and chief executive of the Times Company, said during a conference call with analysts that the company was seeing encouraging signs.
''The large majority of these subscribers have now advanced to paying full rates to access the Times's digital content,'' she said, though she declined to offer a percentage. ''If our experience with print subscribers is any indication, now that these subscribers have converted to full payment, it is highly likely that they will become loyal users.''
The Times said that about 800,000 home delivery customers had linked their accounts to NYTimes.com and now received access free. New orders for print subscriptions continued to increase, the company said, a rise it attributed to the free Web access that accompanies the subscriptions.
Despite charging for online access -- a move many media analysts thought would choke off Web traffic -- NYTimes.com remained the most-visited newspaper site in the world.
Online Correction: October 20, 2011, Thursday
This article has been revised to reflect the following correction: An earlier version of this article incorrectly said print subscriptions rose in the quarter. New print subscription orders and subscriber retentions rose, as did circulation revenue.
